title: df <- data.frame(
text:
#’ Training Status Long to Short Names #’ #’ A dataset containing short names for each status comment. Which makes #’ programming easier. #’ #’ @format A data frame with 23 rows and 2 variables: #’ #’ @source Simulated for demonstration purposes “long_to_short_names”

df <- data.frame(


name = c(“Type”, “Compliance”, “Reason for deviation”, “Details”,


“Strain During”, “Tightness Pre”, “Tightness During”,


“Tightness Post”, “Area”, “Side”, “Pain Pre”, “Pain During”,


“Pain Post”, “Stride changes”, “Downhill tolerance”,


“Overall readiness”, “Sleep quality last night”,


“Accumulated fatigue”, “Motivation before”, “Discipline (rules)”,


“Urge to push beyond plan”, “Elevation”, “Fueling (total)”),


var_name = c(“type”, “compliance”, “deviation”, “details”, “strain_dur”,


“tight_pre”, “tight_dur”, “tight_pos”, “area”, “side”, “pain_pre”,


“pain_dur”, “pain_pos”, “stride”, “downhill”, “readiness”,


“sleep”, “fatigue”, “motivation”, “rules”, “push”, “elevation”,


“fueling”))





saveRDS(df, “data/long_to_short_names.RDS”)

title: Training Status
text:
Volume Development
Changed Heart Rate Zones for all types to the same as running to make it comparable on the 12th of February 2026 (calendar week 2026-W07). Also from this day on I will upload strength training separately. I want to keep track of my strength volume. However, strength training won’t increase TP fitness (TSS set to 0 manually).
